Situation1: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: I was sipping coffee in the break room when my mentee, Sarah, approached me with a worried look. She was torn between two job offers and wanted my advice. As her mentor, I knew she expected me to provide thoughtful guidance, even though I usually just offered casual tips on minor choices. This felt bigger, and I could see how much she needed my support. At the same time, I glanced at the clock and remembered today was voting day. I’d planned to go before work, but in my rush, I’d left my main ID at home. I had a backup in my bag, but I wasn’t sure if it would be accepted. If not, I’d have to go home later to fetch the right one, which would mean missing the window when Sarah was free. The pressure built inside me—Sarah’s anxious eyes on me, the civic duty tugging at my conscience. I felt torn, knowing I couldn’t fully meet both expectations at once. My mind raced, weighing the importance of being present for Sarah against the responsibility of casting my vote.
